critical_finding.battery_eligibility: THEORETICALLY POSSIBLE BUT NOT DESIGNED FOR BATTERIES
critical_finding.reason: EnergyWise Business is primarily an HVAC/thermostat control program with two options: (1) Summer Option: Duke installs smart thermostats to cycle AC equipment, or (2) Winter Option: Customers manually or automatically curtail load during events. While Winter Option allows equipment connection to Duke's control system, program materials focus exclusively on HVAC control, not battery dispatch. Battery participation unclear and likely not practical.
critical_finding.recommendation: NOT RECOMMENDED FOR BATTERY OPTIMIZATION - See PowerShare for better commercial battery DR program

duke_entity_clarification.note: Duke Energy operates two separate utilities in South Carolina

duke_energy_carolinas.customers: ~680,000 retail electric customers in South Carolina
duke_energy_carolinas.coverage: Western South Carolina counties including Abbeville, Anderson, Cherokee, Chester, Fairfield, Greenville, Greenwood, Kershaw, Lancaster, Laurens, McCormick, Newberry, Oconee, Pickens, Saluda, Spartanburg, Union, York

duke_entity_clarification.program_availability: EnergyWise Business is offered by BOTH Duke Energy Carolinas and Duke Energy Progress in South Carolina with same program structure

program_type.description: Duke Energy controls or signals customer equipment (primarily HVAC systems) to reduce load during peak demand periods in exchange for annual incentives
program_type.equipment_type: Smart thermostats (Summer), manual or automated load curtailment (Winter)
program_type.primary_focus: HVAC and equipment control for small to mid-size commercial customers

similarities: Same Summer Option (smart thermostat with AC cycling at 30%/50%/75% levels)
Same Winter Option (manual or automated load curtailment)
Same 40-hour seasonal cap and 2-event opt-out provision
Free equipment and installation for Summer Option

differences.duke_sc_progress: Increased incentive (specific rate not publicly documented - estimated 20-25% increase from previous rate)
differences.note: North Carolina rate explicitly stated as $50/kW. South Carolina rate increase confirmed but exact dollar amount not published in available sources.

differences.duke_sc_progress: Public Service Commission of South Carolina (PSCSC)
Previous rate not documented in available sources

comparison_to_duke_nc_energywise.assumption: Given same program structure and Duke's announcement of 20-25% average incentive increases for business programs in South Carolina, EnergyWise Business SC rate likely in $35-45/kW range, but exact rate not confirmed.

program_details.target_customers: Non-residential Duke Energy Progress electric customers on eligible rates
program_details.minimum_capacity: Not specified - program accommodates small to mid-size businesses
program_details.ownership_model: Summer Option: Duke-provided thermostat; Winter Option: Customer equipment
program_details.compensation_structure: Annual incentive per average kW saved (specific SC rate not publicly documented)
program_details.event_triggers: Unusually high energy demand periods (summer and winter peaks)
participation_types: Summer Option: Smart thermostat installation with automated AC cycling
Winter Option: Manual or automated load curtailment via customer equipment
program_details.seasonality: Both summer and winter programs available
program_details.geographic_scope: Duke Energy Progress service territory in South Carolina

summer_option.description: Duke Energy arranges for an approved contractor to install a smart Wi-Fi programmable thermostat with a secure internet portal at no cost
summer_option.control_method: Automated cycling of central air conditioner compressor or electric heat pump
summer_option.incentive_structure: Higher reduction levels earn higher incentives
summer_option.payment_method: Annual bill credit per participating device

winter_option.description: Customers choose how to participate by connecting equipment to Duke's control system or receiving communications to make manual adjustments
winter_option.control_method: Equipment signal from Duke's control system OR manual adjustment in response to email/text
winter_option.reduction_method: Customer-determined (can connect equipment for automatic response or respond manually)
winter_option.incentive_structure: Annual incentive per average kW reduced across the event season
winter_option.payment_method: Check mailed at end of season
winter_option.requirements: Willingness to curtail load via manual or automatic means

south_carolina_incentive.rate: Not explicitly published in available sources
south_carolina_incentive.general_increase: 20-25% average increase for business energy efficiency programs
south_carolina_incentive.approved_by: Public Service Commission of South Carolina (PSCSC)
south_carolina_incentive.comparison_to_nc: North Carolina rate is $50/kW. South Carolina rate likely different but not documented.

north_carolina_reference.note: This is Duke Energy CAROLINAS in North Carolina - different utility and state than this program

summer_option_payment.basis: Per participating device installed at facility
summer_option_payment.calculation: Based on cycling level chosen at enrollment (30%, 50%, or 75%)

winter_option_payment.basis: Average kW reduced across event season

eligibility_requirements.customer_type: Non-residential Duke Energy Progress electric customers
eligibility_requirements.rate_schedule: Must be on an eligible rate schedule (specific rates not publicly listed)
eligibility_requirements.exclusions: Cannot be participating in another demand response program concurrently

equipment_requirements.winter_option: Ability to curtail load manually or via connected equipment

eligibility_requirements.leased_facilities: Allowed, but property owner may need to sign Tenant Agreement Form
eligibility_requirements.costs: Free - no installation or maintenance charges

event_parameters.notification: Email or text communication for impending curtailment events
event_parameters.seasonal_cap: 40 hours total per season (summer or winter)
event_parameters.override_capability: Customers can override or opt out within allowance limits
event_parameters.timing: During unusually high energy demand periods

reasons: Program designed and marketed exclusively for HVAC control (AC cycling, thermostat management)
Summer Option requires smart thermostat installation - not applicable to batteries
Winter Option allows equipment connection to control system, but no documentation of battery participation
Incentive rate for South Carolina not publicly documented (cannot calculate revenue potential)
Utility control or manual signaling model conflicts with typical battery optimization strategies
No mention of battery storage in any program materials, FAQs, or documentation

theoretical_winter_option_participation.mechanism: Battery could theoretically connect to Duke's control system and discharge during Winter Option events
theoretical_winter_option_participation.incentive_potential: Unknown - SC incentive rate not published
practical_barriers: No documented battery participation pathways or protocols
Program materials do not address battery telemetry, SOC management, or dispatch signals
Unclear if Duke's control system supports battery management systems
Unclear if program accepts 'new load' from battery charging (would offset savings calculation)
Manual response option impractical for battery optimization
theoretical_winter_option_participation.conclusion: While not explicitly prohibited, no evidence of battery participation in practice

powershare_advantages: Larger customer focus (better match for commercial battery systems)
Clear capacity payment structure ($5/kW in SC as of August 1, 2025)
No utility control conflicts with battery charging strategies
energywise_advantages: Potentially higher per-kW incentive rate (unknown for SC)
Free equipment for Summer Option (not relevant for batteries)
comparison_to_powershare.verdict: PowerShare is superior for battery systems due to customer control, technology flexibility, and absence of HVAC-focused program design

revenue_calculation_for_1mw_1mwh_battery.note: Cannot calculate reliable revenue estimate due to lack of published incentive rate and event frequency data

assumptions_if_participation_were_possib.participation_option: Winter Option (only option theoretically compatible with batteries)

scenario_1_if_nc_rate_applies.assumption: IF South Carolina rate equals North Carolina rate of $50/kW

scenario_2_if_20_percent_increase.assumption: IF previous SC rate was similar to NC's pre-increase rate ($30/kW) with 20% increase
scenario_2_if_20_percent_increase.likelihood: Speculative - no data on previous SC rate

scenario_3_if_25_percent_increase.assumption: IF previous SC rate was similar to NC's pre-increase rate ($30/kW) with 25% increase
scenario_3_if_25_percent_increase.likelihood: Speculative - no data on previous SC rate

critical_limitations: NO CONFIRMED INCENTIVE RATE - All revenue calculations are speculative
NO DOCUMENTED BATTERY PARTICIPATION - Program not designed for batteries
NO HISTORICAL EVENT DATA - Cannot verify actual dispatch frequency
HVAC-FOCUSED PROGRAM - Participation pathway for batteries unclear
UTILITY CONTROL MODEL - Conflicts with battery optimization strategies
revenue_calculation_for_1mw_1mwh_battery.conclusion: DO NOT USE THIS PROGRAM FOR BATTERY REVENUE MODELING - Insufficient data and unsuitable program design

market_context.iso_rto: None - Duke Energy Progress is NOT part of any RTO/ISO
market_context.wholesale_market: Southeast Energy Exchange Market (SEEM) - bilateral market, not organized wholesale market
market_context.ferc_jurisdiction: Limited - not subject to FERC Orders 841 or 2222 for battery storage market participation
market_context.explanation: South Carolina (Duke Energy Progress territory) operates as vertically integrated market without competitive wholesale electricity markets. Battery revenue opportunities limited to utility demand response programs and behind-the-meter arbitrage.

regulatory_context.regulator: Public Service Commission of South Carolina (PSCSC)

programs_updated: EnergyWise Business: Increased incentives (specific amount not published)
recent_rate_increases.general_increase: 20-25% average increase for business energy efficiency programs

regulatory_context.rate_case_context: Part of broader Duke Energy demand-side management portfolio optimization in South Carolina

commercial_industrial.incentive: $5.00 per kW capacity payment (SC rate as of August 1, 2025)
commercial_industrial.recommendation: PRIMARY CHOICE for commercial battery systems in Duke Energy Progress territory

commercial_industrial.incentive: Increased rate (specific SC amount not published)

alternative_duke_programs_for_batteries.note: Duke Energy also offers residential battery programs (PowerPair, EnergyWise Home Battery Control) but these are for residential systems only

steps: Visit Duke Energy EnergyWise Business website or contact business customer service
Verify eligibility (non-residential Duke Energy Progress customer on eligible rate, not in another DR program)
Choose Summer Option (smart thermostat) or Winter Option (manual/equipment curtailment)
Complete enrollment application and service agreement
For Summer Option: Schedule free thermostat installation by approved contractor
For Winter Option: Connect equipment to control system or designate contact for manual signals
Begin participating in curtailment events and earning incentives

for_commercial_battery_systems.program_recommendation: DO NOT USE EnergyWise Business - Use PowerShare instead
reasoning: EnergyWise Business is HVAC-focused program not designed for battery systems
PowerShare offers customer-controlled curtailment better suited to battery optimization
PowerShare has documented battery participation pathway (discharge during events)
EnergyWise utility control model conflicts with battery charging/discharging strategies
South Carolina EnergyWise incentive rate not publicly documented (cannot model revenue)
PowerShare SC rate is clearly published at $5/kW as of August 1, 2025

recommended_strategy.primary: Enroll in PowerShare for demand response capacity payments ($5/kW in SC)
recommended_strategy.secondary: Optimize behind-the-meter peak shaving and TOU arbitrage
recommended_strategy.avoid: EnergyWise Business enrollment for battery systems

for_small_commercial_hvac_loads.program_recommendation: EnergyWise Business is EXCELLENT for HVAC control
ideal_customers: Small to mid-size commercial facilities in Duke Energy Progress territory
not_suitable_for: Customers requiring full control over equipment dispatch

historical_events.note: No publicly available historical event data found for Duke Energy Progress EnergyWise Business program in South Carolina
data_gaps: Number of events called per year (2022-2024)

winter_storm_elliott_reference.context: During Winter Storm Elliott, Duke Energy Progress (DEP) and Duke Energy Carolinas (DEC) called upon 200 megawatts of demand response each
winter_storm_elliott_reference.note: This was a grid emergency event. Unclear which specific DR programs were activated or how many EnergyWise Business participants were called.

primary_sources.source: Piclo Energy - Duke Energy Progress EnergyWise Business

Exact percentage increase for EnergyWise Business SC (only 20-25% average cited)
Specific eligible rate schedules for program participation
Whether any battery systems have ever enrolled in Winter Option
Technical specifications for equipment connection to Duke's control system

vs_duke_nc_energywise: STATE: South Carolina vs North Carolina
UTILITY: Duke Energy Progress (SC) vs Duke Energy Carolinas (NC)
PROGRAM STRUCTURE: Same (both Summer/Winter options, 40-hour cap, 2-event opt-out)
vs_powershare_sc: CUSTOMER SIZE: EnergyWise targets smaller businesses, PowerShare targets large C&I
CONTROL: EnergyWise is utility-controlled or signaled, PowerShare is customer-controlled
TECHNOLOGY: EnergyWise is HVAC-focused, PowerShare is technology-agnostic
BATTERY SUITABILITY: PowerShare is battery-compatible, EnergyWise is not battery-focused

accuracy_statement: All data in this file is sourced from official Duke Energy press releases, program websites, and FAQ pages. NO INVENTED DATA. NO MOCK DATA. Program structure, eligibility requirements, and comparisons to other programs are factual as of October 12, 2025. CRITICAL LIMITATION: The specific incentive rate per kW for Duke Energy Progress South Carolina EnergyWise Business is NOT publicly documented in available sources. Revenue calculations are explicitly marked as speculative. Data gaps are explicitly noted where program details are not publicly available.
research_notes: EnergyWise Business is HVAC/thermostat-focused demand response program, NOT designed for battery energy storage systems
Program structure appears identical between Duke Energy Carolinas (NC/SC) and Duke Energy Progress (SC/NC)
South Carolina incentive increases effective August 1, 2025 (vs January 1, 2025 for North Carolina)
CRITICAL DATA GAP: Specific SC incentive rate per kW not published in any available sources
North Carolina rate explicitly stated as $50/kW, but SC rate only described as '20-25% average increase'
Cannot reliably calculate battery revenue potential due to missing incentive rate data
While Winter Option theoretically allows equipment connection to Duke's control system, no documentation exists for battery participation
Program materials exclusively discuss HVAC control, AC cycling, and manual load curtailment - zero mention of batteries
PowerShare is clearly superior program for commercial battery systems ($5/kW, customer-controlled, technology-agnostic)
Duke Energy Progress and Duke Energy Carolinas are separate utilities serving different territories in South Carolina
Both summer and winter programs have 40-hour seasonal cap and 2-event opt-out provision
Free equipment (smart thermostat) is major benefit for HVAC-focused customers but irrelevant for battery systems

comparison_to_index_96.note: Index 96 (program_batch11_006) is Duke Energy Carolinas EnergyWise Business, also in South Carolina
similarities: Same effective date for incentive increase (August 1, 2025)

differences.note: Customer eligibility depends on which Duke Energy utility serves their location

comparison_to_index_96.key_insight: These are the SAME PROGRAM offered by two different Duke Energy utilities serving different geographic territories in South Carolina. A customer can only enroll in the program offered by their utility (cannot choose between them).

final_determination.reason: EnergyWise Business is designed as an HVAC-focused demand response program for small to mid-size commercial customers. Program structure centers on smart thermostat installation (Summer) or manual/signaled load curtailment (Winter) for air conditioning and heating equipment. While Winter Option theoretically allows equipment connection to Duke's control system, there is no documentation, precedent, or technical guidance for battery participation. The utility-controlled or signal-based model conflicts with typical battery optimization strategies requiring precise SOC management, charging schedules, and arbitrage opportunities. Additionally, the specific incentive rate for South Carolina is not publicly documented, making revenue modeling impossible.

for_battery_systems: DO NOT enroll in EnergyWise Business - program not designed for batteries
INSTEAD: Enroll in PowerShare Non-Residential Load Curtailment ($5/kW in SC, customer-controlled)
Focus on behind-the-meter peak shaving and time-of-use arbitrage as primary revenue streams
Use backup power capability as tertiary value stream during grid outages
DO NOT attempt to model revenue from EnergyWise Business due to missing rate data and unsuitable program design
for_hvac_focused_businesses: EnergyWise Business is EXCELLENT program for small commercial facilities with HVAC loads in Duke Energy Progress territory
Free smart thermostat upgrade + incentive payments provide strong value for AC-heavy operations
Both summer and winter options available depending on facility needs
2-event opt-out provision and 40-hour seasonal cap provide reasonable customer flexibility

reasons: South Carolina incentive rate per kW not published
No historical event frequency data available
Program design unsuitable for battery systems
revenue_estimate_for_1mw_battery.recommendation: DO NOT USE THIS PROGRAM FOR BATTERY REVENUE PLANNING

strengths: Comprehensive official Duke Energy sources (news releases, program pages, FAQs)
Recent incentive increase data verified from multiple sources (August 2025)
Clear comparison to Duke NC EnergyWise and PowerShare programs
Detailed program options (Summer vs Winter) with specific parameters
Explicit battery suitability assessment with reasoning
Accurate identification of Duke Energy Carolinas vs Duke Energy Progress distinction
limitations: CRITICAL: Could not find specific incentive rate per kW for South Carolina program
No historical event frequency or timing data available
Could not access full tariff document for complete technical specifications
No confirmation of specific eligible rate schedules
No documentation of actual battery participation (likely because it doesn't happen)
Payment timing details not fully specified in public materials
research_quality.confidence_level: MEDIUM-HIGH - Program structure and parameters clearly documented from official sources, battery unsuitability conclusively determined from program design and materials. However, missing critical data (SC incentive rate) prevents reliable revenue modeling and reduces overall research quality score from 9 to 7.
